results.title: Trek Into Congo Forest Reveals an Ebola Crisis Fueled by Violence
results.abstract: As deadly conflicts shadow health workers, a New York Times reporter and the remote villagers they try to reach, new treatments fail to get to those who need them.

results.title: Japan to Resume Commercial Whaling, Defying International Ban
results.abstract: The country says it will stop its annual hunts in the Antarctic — purportedly carried out for research purposes — and restrict its whalers to Japanese waters.

results.title: Chinese Official Tied to Billionaire Fugitive Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
results.abstract: The sentencing of Ma Jian was the latest sign that President Xi Jinping has no intention of easing his signature anticorruption drive.

multimedia.caption: Ma Jian, a former top security official, in a courtroom in Dalian, China, on Thursday. He was convicted of taking $15.9 million in bribes, committing insider trading and using coercive business practices, the court said.

results.title: Colin O’Brady Completes Crossing of Antarctica With Final 32-Hour Push
results.abstract: O’Brady, 33, covered the final 77.54 miles of his 921-mile journey without sleeping and became the first person ever to traverse Antarctica from coast to coast solo, unsupported and unaided by wind.

multimedia.caption: Colin O’Brady, one of the two men racing to become the first person to trek across Antarctica unassisted, posted this photo on Instagram on the 50th day of his journey.

des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: On the Surface, Hungary Is a Democracy. But What Lies Underneath?
results.abstract: Hungary has the trappings of a 21st-century European democracy, but uses its devices to exert the same kind of control as the autocracies of the Cold War.

results.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 at Libya’s Foreign Ministry, Officials Say
results.abstract: A second assailant was shot and killed by guards before he could detonate explosives hidden in his vest.

multimedia.caption: The scene of the attack at the Foreign Ministry in Tripoli, Libya, on Tuesday.

results.title: As China Cracks Down on Churches, Christians Declare ‘We Will Not Forfeit Our Faith’
results.abstract: China this year banned online sales of the Bible, burned crosses, demolished churches and forced at least a half-dozen places of worship to close.

multimedia.caption: Members of Early Rain, a well-known Protestant church in Chengdu, attended Christmas Eve services elsewhere in the city after the Chinese authorities shut down their church.

results.title: Mexico Helicopter Crash Kills Governor and Her Husband, an Ex-Governor
results.abstract: Martha Erika Alonso, the governor of Puebla, and Rafael Moreno Valle, who once led the same state, were among at least five people who died.
results.byline: By SARAH MERVOSH and MATT STEVENS

multimedia.caption: Martha Erika Alonso, governor of the state of Puebla, at her swearing-in ceremony in Puebla, Mexico, this month.

results.title: Christmas in Lebanon: ‘Jesus Isn’t Only for the Christians’
results.abstract: Few seasons frame the everyday give-and-take of religious coexistence quite like Christmastime in Lebanon, where hijab-wearing women snap selfies in front of Beirut’s colossal Christmas tree.
results.byline: By VIVIAN YEE and HWAIDA SAAD

multimedia.caption: A family at a Christmas-themed display at the City Center mall in Beirut, where children waited in line to whisper wish lists to Santa.
multimedia.copyright: Natalie Naccache for The New York Times
